title.narrative: STRENGTHENED INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY ON SERVICE DELIVERY

description.narrative: By 2023, institutional capacity to deliver quality child protection services, including in emergencies, is strengthened at provincial, communal and community levels, which contributes to Access To Justice, Access To Justice (Covid), Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2023, girls and boys, particularly the most vulnerable, benefit from a child protection system that effectively protects them from violence, abuse and exploitation, including in humanitarian situations

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2023, institutional capacity to deliver quality child protection services, including in emergencies, is strengthened at provincial, communal and community levels

description.narrative: In 2019, UNICEF supported the Ministry of Social Affairs with capacity-building of the social workforce and the progressive establishment of a national case management system. Working with the Ministry of Justice, it supported implementation of child-friendly judicial procedures that benefited 709 children. Critical child protection services were provided to 162,087 vulnerable children (including 63,691 girls) in humanitarian situations. Improved technical capacity of the national birth registration service at provincial and municipal levels led to the registration of 562,191 children (including 286,717 girls). NGO partners included: FENADEB, Association of Women Lawyers, Terres des Hommes, War Child Holland and Fondation Stamm. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:27/12/2019

Number of children, parents and primary caregivers provided with community based mental health and psychosocial support and messaging [COVIDSitRep]
UNICEF targeted children in humanitarian situations benefiting from critical child protection services including PSS, FTR, reintegration
The quality assurance system for social work meets defined standards for normative framework, system of supervision and support, licensing/ accreditation, date collection systems
Existence of procedures and services for children in contact with law that are applied and delivered in line with international norms
